name: Lion
lifespan: 10-14 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Lions are powerful big cats known as the 'King of the Jungle.' They live in prides and are primarily found in the African savannah. Lions are apex predators, relying on teamwork and strength to hunt large prey like zebras and antelopes.
fun_fact: Lions are the only cats that live in groups, called prides.

name: Tiger
lifespan: 10-15 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Tigers are the largest cat species in the world, known for their striking orange coat with black stripes. They are solitary hunters and primarily inhabit forests and grasslands.
fun_fact: Each tiger has a unique pattern of stripes, much like a human fingerprint.

name: Elephant
lifespan: 60-70 years
description: Elephants are the largest land animals on Earth, known for their intelligence and strong social bonds. They are found in various habitats, including savannahs, forests, and grasslands.
fun_fact: Elephants can communicate over long distances using low-frequency sounds.

name: Leopard
lifespan: 12-17 years in the wild, up to 23 years in captivity
description: Leopards are known for their adaptability and strength. They are solitary animals and are found in various habitats, including savannahs, forests, and mountains.
fun_fact: Leopards are excellent climbers and often store their prey in trees.

name: Cheetah
lifespan: 10-12 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Cheetahs are the fastest land animals, capable of reaching speeds up to 75 mph. They are known for their slender bodies and distinctive black tear stripes on their faces.
fun_fact: Cheetahs can accelerate from 0 to 60 mph in just a few seconds.

name: Giraffe
lifespan: 25 years in the wild, up to 30 years in captivity
description: Giraffes are the tallest land animals, known for their long necks and legs. They primarily feed on leaves from tall trees and are found in savannahs and open woodlands.
fun_fact: Giraffes have a unique pattern of spots, which helps them camouflage in their environment.

name: Zebra
lifespan: 25 years in the wild, up to 40 years in captivity
description: Zebras are known for their distinctive black and white stripes. They are social animals that live in herds and are primarily found in African savannahs.
fun_fact: Zebras' stripes are thought to help them confuse predators and regulate their body temperature.

name: Wolf
lifespan: 6-8 years in the wild, up to 16 years in captivity
description: Wolves are highly social animals that live in packs. They are known for their strong family bonds and complex social structures.
fun_fact: Wolves can travel up to 30 miles in a single day while searching for food.

name: Hyena
lifespan: 12-25 years
description: Hyenas are known for their scavenging behavior and social structure. They live in clans and are often misunderstood as mere scavengers.
fun_fact: Hyenas have a unique vocalization known as a 'laugh' that they use to communicate.

name: Rhino
lifespan: 40-50 years
description: Rhinoceroses are large, thick-skinned herbivores known for their horns. They are primarily found in Africa and Asia and are critically endangered due to poaching.
fun_fact: Rhinos can run up to 30 miles per hour despite their size.

name: Panda
lifespan: 20 years in the wild, up to 30 years in captivity
description: Giant pandas are known for their distinctive black and white coloring and primarily eat bamboo. They are native to China and are a symbol of wildlife conservation.
fun_fact: Pandas spend about 10-16 hours a day eating bamboo.

name: Kangaroo
lifespan: 8-12 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Kangaroos are marsupials native to Australia, known for their powerful hind legs and ability to hop. They live in groups called mobs.
fun_fact: Kangaroos can leap over 10 feet in a single bound.

name: Koala
lifespan: 10-12 years in the wild, up to 18 years in captivity
description: Koalas are marsupials native to Australia, known for their tree-dwelling lifestyle and diet of eucalyptus leaves.
fun_fact: Koalas sleep up to 18 hours a day to conserve energy.

name: Crocodile
lifespan: 70-100 years
description: Crocodiles are large reptiles found in tropical regions. They are known for their powerful jaws and stealthy hunting techniques.
fun_fact: Crocodiles can hold their breath underwater for over an hour.

name: Python
lifespan: 20-30 years in captivity
description: Pythons are non-venomous snakes known for their ability to constrict prey. They are found in Africa, Asia, and Australia.
fun_fact: Some pythons can grow over 20 feet long.

name: Falcon
lifespan: 12-16 years in the wild
description: Falcons are birds of prey known for their speed and agility. They are found worldwide and are skilled hunters.
fun_fact: The peregrine falcon is the fastest bird, capable of reaching speeds over 240 mph during a dive.

name: Eagle
lifespan: 20-30 years in the wild
description: Eagles are large birds of prey known for their keen eyesight and powerful flight. They are found in various habitats around the world.
fun_fact: Eagles can see up to four times farther than humans.

name: Vulture
lifespan: 10-30 years in the wild
description: Vultures are scavenging birds known for their role in the ecosystem as cleaners. They primarily feed on carrion.
fun_fact: Vultures have excellent eyesight and can spot food from great distances.

name: Buffalo
lifespan: 15-25 years
description: Buffaloes are large herbivores found in Africa and Asia. They are known for their strength and social behavior.
fun_fact: Buffaloes can run at speeds of up to 40 mph.

name: Jaguar
lifespan: 12-15 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Jaguars are the largest cats in the Americas, known for their powerful build and beautiful rosette-patterned coat. They are solitary hunters and primarily inhabit rainforests.
fun_fact: Jaguars have the strongest bite of all big cats, capable of crushing turtle shells.

name: Sloth
lifespan: 20-30 years
description: Sloths are slow-moving mammals found in Central and South America. They spend most of their lives hanging upside down in trees.
fun_fact: Sloths can hold their breath for up to 40 minutes while swimming.

name: Gorilla
lifespan: 35-40 years in the wild, up to 50 years in captivity
description: Gorillas are the largest primates and are known for their intelligence and strong social structures. They primarily inhabit forests in Africa.
fun_fact: Gorillas share about 98% of their DNA with humans.

name: Orangutan
lifespan: 30-40 years in the wild, up to 60 years in captivity
description: Orangutans are great apes known for their intelligence and tree-dwelling lifestyle. They are native to Indonesia and Malaysia.
fun_fact: Orangutans are the most arboreal of all great apes, spending most of their lives in trees.

name: Hippopotamus
lifespan: 40-50 years
description: Hippopotamuses are large, mostly herbivorous mammals found in sub-Saharan Africa. They spend most of their time in water to keep cool.
fun_fact: Hippos can run up to 19 mph on land despite their size.

name: Otter
lifespan: 10-15 years in the wild
description: Otters are playful aquatic mammals found in rivers, lakes, and oceans. They are known for their social behavior and use of tools.
fun_fact: Otters hold hands while sleeping to keep from drifting apart.

name: Fox
lifespan: 3-4 years in the wild, up to 14 years in captivity
description: Foxes are small to medium-sized canids known for their cunning nature. They are found in various habitats worldwide.
fun_fact: Foxes have a unique way of communicating, using a variety of vocalizations.

name: Polar Bear
lifespan: 20-25 years in the wild, up to 30 years in captivity
description: Polar bears are large carnivorous bears found in the Arctic region. They are excellent swimmers and primarily hunt seals.
fun_fact: Polar bears have black skin under their white fur, which helps them absorb heat from the sun.

name: Lynx
lifespan: 12-15 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Lynxes are medium-sized wild cats known for their tufted ears and short tails. They are found in forests across Europe, Asia, and North America.
fun_fact: Lynxes have excellent night vision, allowing them to hunt effectively in low light.

name: Coyote
lifespan: 6-8 years in the wild, up to 14 years in captivity
description: Coyotes are adaptable canids found throughout North America. They are known for their vocalizations and ability to thrive in various environments.
fun_fact: Coyotes can run up to 40 mph and are known for their clever hunting strategies.

name: Snow Leopard
lifespan: 15-18 years in the wild, up to 20 years in captivity
description: Snow leopards are large cats adapted to cold mountainous regions. They have thick fur and long tails, which help them balance on rocky terrain.
fun_fact: Snow leopards can leap up to six times their body length in a single bound.

name: Komodo Dragon
lifespan: 30 years in captivity
description: Komodo dragons are the largest lizards in the world, found on a few Indonesian islands. They are known for their powerful bite and venomous saliva.
fun_fact: Komodo dragons can consume up to 80% of their body weight in a single meal.

name: Monitor Lizard
lifespan: 10-30 years depending on the species
description: Monitor lizards are large lizards found in Africa, Asia, and Australia. They are known for their intelligence and hunting skills.
fun_fact: Some monitor lizards can swim and are excellent at catching fish.

name: Tortoise
lifespan: 50-100 years depending on the species
description: Tortoises are land-dwelling reptiles known for their hard shells. They are slow-moving and primarily eat plants.
fun_fact: Some tortoises can live for over 150 years.

name: Alligator
population: Around 1.3 million in the wild (American Alligator)
lifespan: 35-50 years in the wild, up to 65 years in captivity
description: Alligators are large reptiles found in freshwater environments in the southeastern United States and China. They are known for their powerful jaws.
fun_fact: Alligators can hold their breath underwater for up to 2 hours.

name: Tasmanian Devil
lifespan: 5-8 years in the wild, up to 10 years in captivity
description: Tasmanian devils are small marsupials native to Tasmania. They are known for their loud screeches and scavenging behavior.
fun_fact: Tasmanian devils have a powerful bite and can consume up to 40% of their body weight in one meal.

name: Wolverine
lifespan: 7-12 years in the wild, up to 15 years in captivity
description: Wolverines are stocky and muscular carnivores found in remote northern regions. They are known for their strength and ferocity.
fun_fact: Wolverines can travel long distances in search of food, covering up to 15 miles in a day.

name: Pangolin
lifespan: 10-20 years in the wild
description: Pangolins are unique mammals covered in protective keratin scales. They are primarily found in Asia and Africa and are known for their ability to curl into a ball.
fun_fact: Pangolins are the only mammals with scales and can consume up to 70 million insects in a year.

name: Red Panda
lifespan: 8-10 years in the wild, up to 15 years in captivity
description: Red pandas are small, tree-dwelling mammals native to the eastern Himalayas and southwestern China. They are known for their reddish-brown fur and playful behavior.
fun_fact: Red pandas are more closely related to raccoons than to giant pandas.

name: Manatee
lifespan: 50-65 years
description: Manatees, also known as sea cows, are large marine mammals found in warm coastal waters. They are gentle and primarily feed on seagrass.
fun_fact: Manatees can hold their breath underwater for up to 20 minutes.

name: Armadillo
lifespan: 4-7 years in the wild, up to 15 years in captivity
description: Armadillos are small to medium-sized mammals known for their armored shells. They are primarily found in the Americas and are excellent diggers.
fun_fact: Armadillos can hold their breath for up to six minutes while swimming.

name: Okapi
lifespan: 20-30 years in captivity
description: Okapis are unique mammals native to the rainforests of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. They are closely related to giraffes and have zebra-like stripes on their legs.
fun_fact: Okapis have a long, prehensile tongue that they use to grasp leaves and twigs.

name: Capybara
lifespan: 8-10 years in the wild, up to 12 years in captivity
description: Capybaras are the largest rodents in the world, native to South America. They are social animals that live in groups near water bodies.
fun_fact: Capybaras are excellent swimmers and can hold their breath underwater for up to five minutes.

name: Bison
lifespan: 15-20 years in the wild, up to 25 years in captivity
description: Bison are large, grazing mammals native to North America. They are known for their massive size and thick fur.
fun_fact: Bison can run at speeds of up to 35 mph.

name: Hedgehog
lifespan: 3-7 years in the wild, up to 10 years in captivity
description: Hedgehogs are small, nocturnal mammals known for their spiny coats. They are found in Europe, Asia, and Africa.
fun_fact: Hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball to protect themselves from predators.

name: Chinchilla
lifespan: 10-15 years in captivity
description: Chinchillas are small rodents native to the Andes mountains in South America. They are known for their incredibly soft fur.
fun_fact: Chinchillas can jump up to six feet high.

name: Quokka
lifespan: 10-12 years
description: Quokkas are small marsupials native to Australia, known for their friendly demeanor and 'smiling' faces.
fun_fact: Quokkas are often referred to as the 'world's happiest animal.'
